Tenzin Tsundue, a Tibetan writer and activist in Dharamshala, told VOA that the force was trained by the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) in the 1960s.  “At that time, the main purpose of the group was to fight the PLA across the border,” he said. The Tibetan troops obtained weapons and equipment as well as training from the CIA, he said.  The U.S. government pulled the CIA out of the training program following then-Republican President Richard M. Nixon’s visit to China in 1972. I find it difficult to figure out what about these reports are failing to meet the criteria. A person (or more) has died, in a conflicted region, and unless the resolution is contingent on the definition of "between" as in "between: one dude with a gun and another dude with a gun...one died" as the only satisfactory resolution to accept then I'm beyond confused. Even a landmine was placed by someone, so unless the dead are mining their own fields and then haphazardly walking through them the issue is closed. @Daveinsea is putting out a lot of interesting and important info.

There are clearly deaths occurring, though the point of contentions for me are twofold... The first is in the wording of the question itself, as we don't know enough about the deaths occurring, it is hard to speculate, especially given the specificity of the question.; for a "lethal confrontation" to have occurred. Regarding instances of 'landmines,' and other 'device related' deaths, (though obviously abhorrent,) we can say that these are not, technically, 'confrontational,' (as per dictionary definitions).
This lack of clarity and evidence is the ONLY thing stopping me from jumping significant percentages here! Secondly, and equally importantly, is the idea that changes to the outcome of the question may occur in hindsight, ("hindsight changes!") 
I find this ridiculous, as forecasters can only go by the AVAILABLE evidence. If the information/evidence that India-China were "lethally confrontational" WAS available, and was missed in hindsight, then our scores may indeed (and fairly) be subject to change after the outcome. HOWEVER, if the information/evidence was/is NOT publicly available at a given time, (as appears to be the case with India-China confrontations,) then the outcome should NOT change, even if, in hindsight, it is indeed found to be wrong. *Otherwise, this is ignoring historical context, to fit our new understanding. Like judging Native American "rain dances" by the standards of modern Meteorology....or something.
**Has/is/will confrontation occur? Likely, yes. Is there concrete evidence corroborating? No, there isn't, that I can see/have seen!? Certainly not evidence to fulfil the question's parameters.
It would be nice to have some clarification on arising resolution issues.

Aasif Suhaf, Ladakh:
"In a serious escalation that could further worsen the already tense situation along the Line of Actual Control (LAC) in Ladakh, the People’s Liberation Army (PLA) and Indian Army engaged in fresh clashes on Friday night.
There are reports of casualties among the PLA troops as they tried to evict the Indian Army from the Black Top and Helmet Top positions on the southern bank of the Pangong Tso.
According to sources, the Chinese soldiers faced stiff resistance and the Indian Army foiled the PLA's attempt to regain its lost positions. Sources said that the PLA soldiers were seen carrying their men on stretchers back to their side of the LAC.
An additional three companies of the Indian Army were rushed to the strategically important positions.
Sources said that the Indian Army was anticipating an offensive from the PLA and was ready to counter the measures. The Indian Army had also laid barbed wires around their freshly acquired positions at the Black Top and Helmet Top.  
The clashes have taken place despite the fact that the foreign ministries of China and India had agreed in a joint statement that their troops must quickly disengage from a months-long standoff along the Line of Actual Control (LAC).
There is no word yet from the Indian Army about the incident."

THE TIBETAN ARMY On August 31, just hours after the Indian Army’s press statement, the Tibetan community in the Union territory buzzed with WhatsApp messages. The messages in English and Tibetan said that Nyima Tenzing, 51, of the ‘7 Vikas’ battalion had been killed in a landmine blast in which another Tibetan jawan was seriously injured. Tenzing’s body was driven home to his house in the Sonamling Tibetan Refugee settlement in Leh, Ladakh, escorted by a Special Frontier Force (SFF) truck and handed over to his family. But for the tragic death of this Non-Commissioned Officer (NCO), an extremely significant fact would have escaped the theatre of operations. For the first time in recent years, India had deployed its secret Tibetan paramilitary force along the LAC with China. In Ladakh, the SFF acted in concert with the army to occupy the three features on the ridgeline. Among these units was the Chushul-based 7 Vikas. “China’s position is very clear. We oppose any country, and of course that includes India, which provides any facilitation or venue to forces advocating Tibetan independence,” Chinese ministry of foreign affairs (MoFA) spokesperson Hua Chunying said on September 2, responding to a question on the SFF. The Tibetan force deployments in the Ladakh theatre, in fact, began soon after the Chinese incursions in May this year. The Indian Army pulled out its special forces units trained in high-altitude warfare to hack trails and set up posts along hilltops and ridgelines to observe PLA positions. They were joined in these reconnaissance tasks by an unspecified number of Vikas battalions that surged forward to man key positions along the LAC.

The two Asian giants have held several rounds of talks, mainly involving military commanders, without success. In a sign that the talks are now shifting to the political level, their defense ministers met in the Russian capital on Friday to try end the impasse. It was the first high-level direct contact between the sides since the standoff erupted in the Ladakh region four months ago ... Last week, the world’s two most populous nations, which share thousands of kilometers (miles) of disputed border, accused each another of fresh provocations, including allegations of soldiers crossing into each other’s territory." https://apnews.com/d27ec36d89d5b8011ebaaeef2983809f

On the one hand: Both countries are nuclear powers and have a lot to lose. One is generally thought to be a rising superpower (India) one is arguably there already (China) Not only are they strongly incentivized to avoid coming into open warfare, every other significant actor in world politics is incentivized to keep them from coming into open warfare as well. Likely there’s a lot of behind the scenes diplomacy we are not seeing with the goal of preventing said war.
Previous border disputes between China and India have typically followed a pattern of clashes followed by de-escalation (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sino-Indian_border_dispute) Chinese official media have not made much of the incident. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_China%E2%80%93India_skirmishes). To me, this indicates that the Chinese government is not interested in pursuing further belligerence; if they were they would be rallying support from their people. There’s always the possibility of change in policy due to opaque dynamics within the party, but I believe this to be unlikely. Xi Jinping seems secure in his power and will probably not be swayed by fire-eaters. Modi, likewise, enjoys strong approval ratings (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narendra_Modi#Personal_life_and_image) and does not seem like he is vulnerable to being pressured into highly aggressive action. His reputation as a nationalist and his previous aggressive action in Jammu and Kashmir give him a certain freedom of maneuver here. On the other hand: Although both sides have taken steps to reduce their troop presence in the reason, it looks like India is is committed to developing their infrastructure in the region (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-53171124). This is unlikely to put China at ease. On the whole, I think we can probably expect tensions on the border to increase rather than decrease over the next decade.  It’s possible that I have actually inverted the relationship between Modi’s political base and his freedom of maneuver. It could be that having made his reputation as a hardliner, he feels compelled to live up to it and escalates the situation. I don’t think that’s the case but I’m obviously an expert on Indian politics.

The Line of Actual Control (LAC) is the ill-defined and disputed border between India and China in the Himalayas.
Tensions had been building and have resulted in a violent clash of soldiers armed with rocks and clubs. (Weapons are not allowed as per earlier agreements).
China was understood to have been aggrieved over India’s decision to strip Kashmir of its special status and also to the road and bridge infrastructure, while China involved itself in earthmoving activities and redirecting the river that defined the border.
Although India became very vocal about the arguments and transgressions, China downplayed the affair, signalling a low importance.
Both sides have pulled back their troops, with the Indian Prime Minister, Modi, denying any loss of property to the Chinese.
Given the present climate of Covid-19 pandemic and economic issues confronting the two countries and the lack of advantage to be gained this time by either side, the skirmishes are probably locally inspired rather than inspired by Delhi or Beijing.
The potential of a lethal confrontation between the armed forces of either side should be considered extremely high given the volatile nature of the local tensions, but an escalation into a major conflict is very low.

Ultimately this is a gut feeling estimate rather than a more quantifiable metric. Given that 15 June was the first fatal clash in 45 years there is no reliable statistical soure to base estimates on the number of annual clashes vs the number that escalate to fatalities. 15 June was the first fatal incident between India & China in 45 years. The most recent conflict precipitated by Chinese forces objecting to India road construction in Galwan River valley (undisputed Indian territory, but Chinese don’t like the strategic implications). Fighting on 15/16 June resulted in 20 Indian dead and some Chinese casualties. China claims that “Indian border troops have unilaterally and continuously built roads, bridges and other facilities at the LAC in the Galwan Valley”. China have themselves been pitching tents in a disputed area of the Galwan Valley; this is reportedly part of a Chinese pattern, whereby they pitch tents, then move back after bilateral military-talks, but do not remove or destroy the tents. Positive modifiers (Strategic):
China is raising border issues due to internal problems within China and the international pressure being exerted on China over COVID-19.
Current border tensions have been linked to India's decision to abrogate Article 370 and change the status of Jammu and Kashmir in 2019.
PLA has brought in 6000 extra troops
In response to the first incident India has sent 12,000 additional workers to help complete development of infrastructure.
China captured 60 km2 of Indian-patrolled territory between May and June 2020. Will India try to regain this? Positive modifiers (Local):
India has loosened its Rules of Engagement, sanctioning use of firearms in ‘extraordinary’ circumstances. The Indian Army have been given full freedom to deal with on-ground situation.
India has something to prove, ‘blood raised’ on both sides. Any ground interactions between patrols could easily escalate to fatal clashes unintentionally. Negative modifiers (Strategic):
China has (largely) achieved its goal, pushing gaining 60 km2 of Indian territory. A period of consolidation to allow tensions to cool would be strategically sensible.
Numerous Indian government officials said that border tensions will not impact trade between India and China despite some Indian campaigns about boycotting Chinese products. This appears part of a wider intent within the Indian government to prevent further strategic escalation. My estimate leans towards no for all of the reasons above, with the primary reasons being due to China having largely achieved their strategic goals, and India largely being unwilling to escalate to a true inter-state conflict. The residual risk therefore (whilst significant) is due to the potential for local escalation between patrols rather than larger scale strategies on either side. This will accordingly be modified as information comes to light regarding troop numbers and other information between now and September.
Given the disengagement is well underway and will be supervised and cross verified, it's almost certain that there would be no more causalities
My forecast remains tethered to the aggregate. My comparative pessimism hasn't moved, but the aggregate has (likely because the Indian/China resolution proceeds more smoothly.)

The Line of Actual Control has a stark similarity to the Nine Dash Line of the South China Sea.  Discontinuity and disagreed upon.  But there’s also a stark contrast in availability of and location of available resources in each region. The SCS is plentiful in resources and except for China, accepted universally under the 200 mile UN Convention on the Law of the Sea.  China has ignored the UN and chosen to strong arm the Phillipines, Vietnam and others into resource submission. The LAC that divides China from India runs through the extremes of mountain and valley terrain, is of interest only to the immediate countries, but abundant in water and a few minerals. A major deposit of zinc/lead was discovered in the disputed Aksai Chin region and mining initiated three years ago by Guanghui Energy.  This area of Aksai Chin is secured by China.
The Galwan valley is of military interest in maintaining Aksai Chin security along with river control. 
China seeks land in the valley and has artificially altered the path of river to create newly occupied Chinese land in the valley.  A patient geographic usurper, the Galwan River activity is now reminiscent of the artificial island buildup in the SCS.  The recent altercation proves tension is high, especially without intervention of the International community.  So a subsequent battle seems inevitable, but more than likely will happen after September 30th.  China as whole needs to maintain a semblance of its eastern relations, or India will further sympathize with Western discontent. India will continue construction of the DS-DBO road, and China will intermittently chip away at the border, leading to another confrontation.  The plan seems to rely on action surreptitious to the international media and scrutiny, so will go dormant for a time, and will vacillate between each countries macro and micro objectives.

I think China will take advantage of the rest of the world (and India!) being focused on covid to see what they can get away with in this region.

There are lots of countervailing factors increasing/decreasing the likely probability in this one. I found it important to consider the different dimensions of the question as regards actors who could influence the result: state level actors with geopolitical considerations, army generals (+ ministers) with strategic considerations, and individual soldiers.  Overall, I find the probability to be quite a bit lower than the average. Without going fully into the reasons, some of which are mirrored (and stolen from) other forecasters, two observations are: 
(1)	Despite Indian troops being given greater autonomy, increasing the chance of an individual incident, I still believe that non-lethal confrontations/stand-offs are possible, as have happened in the past. This gives room for the inevitable conflicts to be solved without lethal consequences. 
(2)	Although the escalation of tensions means this period of time bears higher risk than normal, the border conflict is still an ongoing long-term issue and the time quoted in the question is relatively short. Unfortunately for the world, I do believe it is likely the conflict will cause further loss of life, but I think that some of the probabilities quoted (90%+) are not appropriate for a three month period.

Ultimately this is a gut feeling estimate rather than a more quantifiable metric. Given that 15 June was the first fatal clash in 45 years there is no reliable statistical soure to base estimates on the number of annual clashes vs the number that escalate to fatalities. 15 June was the first fatal incident between India & China in 45 years. The most recent conflict precipitated by Chinese forces objecting to India road construction in Galwan River valley (undisputed Indian territory, but Chinese don’t like the strategic implications). Fighting on 15/16 June resulted in 20 Indian dead and some Chinese casualties. China claims that “Indian border troops have unilaterally and continuously built roads, bridges and other facilities at the LAC in the Galwan Valley”. China have themselves been pitching tents in a disputed area of the Galwan Valley; this is reportedly part of a Chinese pattern, whereby they pitch tents, then move back after bilateral military-talks, but do not remove or destroy the tents. Positive modifiers (Strategic):
China is raising border issues due to internal problems within China and the international pressure being exerted on China over COVID-19.
Current border tensions have been linked to India's decision to abrogate Article 370 and change the status of Jammu and Kashmir in 2019.
PLA has brought in 6000 extra troops
In response to the first incident India has sent 12,000 additional workers to help complete development of infrastructure.
China captured 60 km2 of Indian-patrolled territory between May and June 2020. Will India try to regain this? Positive modifiers (Local):
India has loosened its Rules of Engagement, sanctioning use of firearms in ‘extraordinary’ circumstances. The Indian Army have been given full freedom to deal with on-ground situation.
India has something to prove, ‘blood raised’ on both sides. Any ground interactions between patrols could easily escalate to fatal clashes unintentionally. Negative modifiers (Strategic):
China has (largely) achieved its goal, pushing gaining 60 km2 of Indian territory. A period of consolidation to allow tensions to cool would be strategically sensible.
Numerous Indian government officials said that border tensions will not impact trade between India and China despite some Indian campaigns about boycotting Chinese products. This appears part of a wider intent within the Indian government to prevent further strategic escalation. My estimate leans towards no for all of the reasons above, with the primary reasons being due to China having largely achieved their strategic goals, and India largely being unwilling to escalate to a true inter-state conflict. The residual risk therefore (whilst significant) is due to the potential for local escalation between patrols rather than larger scale strategies on either side. This will accordingly be modified as information comes to light regarding troop numbers and other information between now and September.
Confrontation likely given history and nature of dispute.

Neither country seems to shows opportunity to gain by a conflict.  There is always a chance a loose nut causes the wheel to fall off, so 5%

Previous forecast which was pegged at 5% till the recent incident: "The only clash between China and India in the past which resulted in fatalities was the Sino-Indian conflict in 1967. After that incident, there were 5 incidents of stand-offs including this current one starting May 2020 (year of incidents: 2013, 2014, 2015, 2017, 2020). Fights are likely to occur between troops, but are usually restricted to hands, or blunt weapons. It seems highly unlikely that there will be deaths resulting from fists or blunt weapons, although the forecast needs to be adjusted for the unlikely scenario of a lucky strike to the head. The recent border disputes have started since XJP and Modi came to power (2013 for XJP, 2014 for Modi). Both are seen as nationalists and strongmen who want to build their internal base up while maintaining a strong exterior to the world. This mentality has fueled the disputes over the past 5 years, although stopping short of ordering troops to attack each other with non-blunt weapons to prevent a regional war. Border disputes started in 2013 when XJP took power and wanted to exert control over China's military through a show of force (https://www.theatlantic.com/china/archive/2013/05/are-china-and-india-about-to-fight-over-their-border/275518/). 2014, 2015, 2017 clashes seemed to be about small incursions from construction equipment into disputed territory and usually ahead of Indo-Sino summits. In 2020, China has ramped up its national security policies. All other nations except for US have not reacted strongly to the new nationalistic push by XJP. If Modi continues to stay on the sidelines, I do not believe that this clash will result in any fatalities as the orders from the top will continue to keep the troops in check."
